channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Loki and Star Wars: The Bad Batch get Disney+ premiere dates
item.description: Also: the new Spider-Man movie has a name.

item.title: Fed glitch shuts down wire transfers, direct deposits, other services
item.description: A Fed statement attributed the outage to “operational error.”

item.title: Biden admin plans executive order to address chip-shortage woes
item.description: Semiconductor demand isn’t going to drop, but supply has proven a problem.

item.title: Cox’s bad customer service stymies users who don’t want upload speeds cut
item.description: Cox told media that customers can keep speed plans but didn’t tell sales reps.

item.title: Firefox 86 brings multiple Picture-in-Picture, “Total Cookie Protection”
item.description: Despite a steadily slipping market share, Firefox is snappy and feature-forward.

item.title: Lone high-energy neutrino likely came from shredded star in distant galaxy
item.description: Provides evidence that tidal disruption events can also be cosmic particle accelerators.

item.title: Ukraine says Russia hacked its document portal and planted malicious files
item.description: Ukraine says Russia also backed massive DDoS attack using never-before-seen methods.

item.title: EA, BioWare cancel Anthem’s sweeping overhaul
item.description: Casey Hudson, who had led BioWare’s plans for “reinvention,” left in December.

item.title: LG enters fray with Google, Amazon, Roku for TV operating system dominance
item.description: Licensees will use an older version of the OS, though.

item.title: Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine safe and effective, FDA review concludes
item.description: An advisory committee for the agency will further review the vaccine this Friday.

item.title: Google Maps for Android officially gets dark mode support
item.description: Google Maps is the last major Google app to support dark mode.

item.title: USPS picks a new mail truck—and no, they won’t all be electric [Updated]
item.description: Oshkosh Defense will design and build 50,000-165,000 NGDV trucks over 10 years.

item.title: D-Wave’s hardware outperforms a classic computer
item.description: The company’s quantum annealer handles complexity better than a traditional CPU.

item.title: Hyundai will recall 82,000 Kona EVs to replace batteries
item.description: South Korea’s transport ministry blames LG Chem, LG Chem blames Hyundai.

item.title: China officially plans to move ahead with super-heavy Long March 9 rocket
item.description: The rocket would have more lift than even the most powerful version of NASA’s SLS.

item.title: California can enforce net neutrality law, judge rules in loss for ISPs
item.description: Judge denies injunction, letting Calif. enforce law while ISPs' suit continues.

item.title: Android users now have an easy way to check the security of their passwords
item.description: Feature checks user credentials against a list of billions of compromised passwords.

item.title: Confirmed: Fry’s Electronics going out of business, shutting down all stores
item.description: Former king of build-your-own-PC retailers couldn’t survive COVID, consignment shift.

item.title: Scientists create new class of “Turing patterns” in colonies of E. coli
item.description: Computer science pioneer Alan Turing first proposed the patterning mechanism in 1952.

item.title: Garden-variety germs may explode in COVID’s wake, study suggests
item.description: In coronavirus’s wake, garden-variety germs may come roaring back.

item.title: Attack of the Murder Hornets is a nature doc shot through horror/sci-fi lens
item.description: Director Michael Paul Stephenson brings his unique sensibility to documentary genre.

item.title: Grab a recommended Anker indoor security camera for $30 today
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Nintendo Joy-Cons, gaming monitors, and more.

item.title: Pixel 5a leak shows a headphone jack, flat screen, and a familiar design
item.description: The Pixel 5a design is a case of “if it’s not broke, don’t fix it.”

item.title: Lenovo updates ThinkPad lineup with 16:10 screens and more
item.description: The new laptops launch this spring.

item.title: Facebook to reverse Australia news ban after lawmakers alter bill
item.description: Australian Facebook users' News Feeds can once again have actual news in them.

item.title: SEC halts trading of iced tea company that pivoted to blockchain
item.description: The company’s blockchain business “never became operational,” SEC says.

item.title: The Ars Technica low-end USB shootout
item.description: Tired of everything being 4.5+ stars on Amazon? We’ll show you the real winners.

item.title: Sony announces new PSVR hardware for PlayStation 5
item.description: New headset coming after 2021 will have higher resolution and new controllers.

item.title: Samsung now updates Android for longer than Google does
item.description: Galaxy devices going back to 2019 are now getting four years of security updates.

item.title: Jeep asked to change name of its SUV by the Cherokee Nation
item.description: The Jeep Cherokee name “does not honor us,” says Cherokee Nation Chief Hoskin.

item.title: Musk: Starlink will hit 300Mbps and expand to “most of Earth” this year
item.description: SpaceX CEO teases higher speeds, lower latency, and near-global coverage.

item.title: Chip shortage may threaten PlayStation 5 supplies at Christmas
item.description: Sony’s gaming chief refuses to guarantee there will be enough consoles to meet demand.

item.title: A politician who said politicians shouldn’t run NASA wants to run NASA
item.description: “Now is not the time to turn back the clock at NASA.”

item.title: The bitcoin blockchain is helping keep a botnet from being taken down
item.description: Wallet transactions camouflage the IP address of the botnet’s control server.

item.title: $200 Puro Pro hybrid over-the-ear headphones are almost perfect
item.description: These full-featured, flagship Bluetooth headphones impressed us mightily.

item.title: Here’s the first of Hyundai’s new 800-volt EVs—the Ioniq 5
item.description: Due this fall, it features clever fast-charging tech and an expansive interior.

item.title: Epic will pay off class-action loot-box settlement with in-game currency
item.description: Fortnite and Rocket League players will get over $78 million in digital goods.

item.title: Humans had never seen a spacecraft land on another planet—until now
item.description: “I can, and have, watched those videos for hours.”

item.title: Microsoft throws Google under the bus in European news fight
item.description: Google has blasted “link tax” proposals as antithetical to the open Web.

item.title: Huawei’s new $2,800 foldable phone copies Samsung’s Galaxy Fold line
item.description: The phone looks great, but can Huawei even get the parts for it?

item.title: AT&T and Frontier have let phone networks fall apart, Calif. regulator finds
item.description: AT�T raised phone prices 153% over a decade as service got steadily worse.

item.title: Software bugs reportedly keep Arizona inmates jailed past release dates
item.description: State law was updated in 2019, but the state’s software suite still hasn’t been.

item.title: Apple beats Samsung in phone sales for first time since 2016
item.description: Apple sold almost 80 million phones in Q4 2020.

item.title: Self-driving companies are inching toward fully driverless service
item.description: Motional has completed 100,000 rides with safety drivers in Las Vegas.

item.title: Blaming a wiggly jet stream on climate change? Not so fast
item.description: The hypothesis is easy to understand, but it’s far from a consensus.

item.title: Consumer Reports creates a “green choice” for vehicle reviews
item.description: The publication will now grade vehicles according to their environmental impact.

item.title: Take-Two DMCA takes down reverse-engineered GTA source code
item.description: EULA prohibitions likely prevent any fair use arguments.

item.title: After Saturday’s engine failure, Boeing says many 777s should be grounded
item.description: Many of the engine components fell over populated areas.

item.title: A curious observer’s guide to quantum mechanics, pt 7: The quantum century
item.description: Manipulating quantum devices has been like getting an intoxicating new superpower for society.

item.title: The AI research paper was real. The “co-author” wasn’t
item.description: An MIT professor found his name on two papers with which he had no connection.

item.title: New malware found on 30,000 Macs has security pros stumped
item.description: With no payload, analysts are struggling to learn what this mature malware does.

item.title: As coronavirus variants spread, the US struggles to keep up
item.description: Without federal strategy or enough funding, US sequencing superpowers don’t work.
